newsitem.title: INDIA: India to set up agency for coal exploration.
newsitem.headline: India to set up agency for coal exploration.

text.p: India will set up an independent agency to coordinate exploration for coal and lignite, Coal Minister Kanti Singh said.

The agency would also have responsibility for allocating the new exploration blocks through competitive bidding, a Coal Ministry statement quoted Singh as telling a meeting of parliamentary deputies on Tuesday.
The creation of an independent agency follows the recommendation of a committee on integrated coal policy, the statement said.
India in February opened up the domestic coal industry allowing private companies to bid for coal and lignite blocks with or without foreign participation.
Singh said that a regulatory body would also be set up to resolve price disputes between coal producers and consumers.
Outstanding debt owed by consumers to coal companies stood at 39.42 billion rupees out of which power firms owe 32.55 billion rupees, she said.
Coal output during the first quarter of 1997-98 (April-March) rose to 57.78 million tonnes, up 7.0 per cent from 54.01 million in the corresponding period in the previous year.
